text: hang on oh man
kind of difficult because you know I
really can't deny that they get you know
emotionally affected but like I've said
as much as possible I want to you know
detach from that kind of thing if you're
an aid worker you you you really have to
control your feelings for you to be very
objective in the things that you do but
when you're working in your country
that's different we know you're a human
being you're you get affected and what
happens to your people and the stories
that they tell you so such a thing that
this happened to me to a place where I
belong to a place that I that I call a
home and I also saw the house of my aunt
and it was just so dismissive to see
that the house was no longer there what
was left was this little store of my
aunt and then the mango trees we used to
enjoy the fruits of that mango tree but
now it was it was a source of
destruction for the house because we saw
it was falling down onto the roof of
that house
first saw the video footage of the
impact of typhoon haiyan I was like I
didn't say anything I cried you know the
feeling of working is double triple the
back of my mind the affected families
came from among the poorest provinces of
the country you know it's good to help
but it's like a sad thing also because I
grew up from somewhere here but I'm
coming back because I'm going to see you
know people who are suffering from the

manage to hold on to my feelings you
